content: The "Executive Appointee Ethics Improvement Act" is the short title of the Act. It includes amendments to Section 207 of Title 18. The "Executive Appointee Ethics Improvement Act" amends Section 207 of Title 18 by extending the post-employment ban on lobbying for certain former government employees from one year to two years. Waivers granted must be published in the Federal Register within 30 days. The "Executive Appointee Ethics Improvement Act" extends the post-employment lobbying ban for certain former government employees from one year to two years. Waivers granted must be publicly disclosed within 30 days. Additionally, a lifetime ban on representing foreign entities is imposed on high-level former employees. The "Executive Appointee Ethics Improvement Act" extends the post-employment lobbying ban for certain former government employees from one year to two years and imposes a lifetime ban on representing foreign entities for high-level former employees. Individuals subject to the lifetime ban include those employed in specific government positions or in confidential or policy-determining roles. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON PARTICIPATION IN MATTER RELATING TO PREVIOUS EMPLOYMENT. Section 220 of Chapter 11 of title 18, United States Code, prohibits individuals appointed to a covered position at an agency from participating in specific matters related to their former employer or clients for a 2-year period. This includes individuals who were registered lobbyists or engaged in lobbying activities in the 2 years before their appointment. This includes individuals who were registered lobbyists or engaged in lobbying activities in the 2 years before their appointment. Violators shall be punished as provided in section 216 of this title. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Counsel to the President, may waive these restrictions. Waivers can be granted for exigent circumstances related to public health, public safety, or national security, and any waiver must be published in the Federal Register with detailed reasoning provided by the Director. Lobbying activity is defined as knowingly influencing government officials on behalf of another person, with specific criteria for individuals spending over 20% of their time in such activities. The text chunk discusses the criteria for a firm or organization to be considered a lobbying organization, based on the number of lobbying contacts made and the amount of money received for lobbying activities. This is in line with the regulations set forth in the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995. The text chunk defines the term 'employee' and 'agency' in relation to the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995. It also explains the meaning of 'covered position' in the context of lobbying activities. The text chunk defines a 'covered position' as a full-time, non-career position appointed by the President or Vice-President, a non-career position within the Senior Executive Service, or a position excepted from competitive service due to being of a confidential or policymaking nature. It excludes individuals appointed as members of the Senior Foreign Service or solely as uniformed service commissioned officers. The term 'former client' refers to individuals for whom the person served as an agent, attorney, or consultant, excluding cases where services were limited to speeches or clients of the former employer. The term 'former employer' pertains to entities where the individual held positions such as employee, officer, director, trustee, or general partner in the two years before appointment. The term 'lobbying contact' is defined in the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995, 'particular matter' is defined in federal regulations, 'participate' means personal and substantial involvement, and 'particular matter involving specific parties' is defined in regulations. The text chunk discusses the expansion of the definition of lobbying contact to include communication related to an individual's official duties with a former employer or client, unless it pertains to a matter of general applicability.
